Literature Review: Microbubbles, defined as gas-filled bubbles with diameters typically ranging from 1 to 100 micrometers, have gained significant attention in various fields, including food technology, due to their unique properties and potential applications. This literature review aims to explore the current state of knowledge regarding microbubbles in food technology, focusing on their generation, applications in cleaning and disinfection, contributions to food properties, and use in supporting living organisms.Microbubble Generation Techniques:The generation of microbubbles is a critical aspect of their application in food technology. Several methods have been developed to produce microbubbles with controlled size distributions and stability. Zimmerman et al. (2011) described a fluidic oscillation method for generating microbubbles, which offers advantages in terms of energy efficiency and bubble size control. Another widely used technique is ultrasonic cavitation, as reported by Yasui et al. (2011), which can produce microbubbles with diameters as small as a few micrometers.Cleaning and Disinfection Applications:One of the most promising applications of microbubbles in food technology is their use in cleaning and disinfection processes. Agarwal et al. (2012) demonstrated that microbubbles can enhance the efficacy of cleaning agents by increasing their penetration into food residues and biofilms. The high surface area-to-volume ratio of microbubbles allows for improved contact between cleaning agents and contaminants, leading to more efficient removal of debris and microorganisms.In terms of disinfection, Tsai et al. (2009) showed that ozone microbubbles exhibit superior antimicrobial activity compared to conventional ozone treatment methods. The increased dissolution of ozone in water, facilitated by microbubbles, results in higher concentrations of reactive oxygen species, which are responsible for the inactivation of microorganisms.Enhancement of Food Properties:Microbubbles have shown potential in modifying the functional and mechanical properties of food materials. Shen et al. (2008) investigated the impact of microbubbles on the texture of bread dough, reporting improvements in dough stability and gas retention during fermentation. This resulted in enhanced bread volume and improved crumb structure.In the dairy industry, Datta et al. (2011) explored the use of microbubbles in the production of low-fat ice cream. The incorporation of microbubbles led to improved texture and mouthfeel, mimicking the properties of full-fat ice cream while reducing overall fat content.Supporting Living Organisms:Microbubbles have shown promise in supporting the growth of living organisms in hydroponic systems and bioreactors. Park and Kurata (2009) demonstrated that the use of microbubbles in hydroponic nutrient solutions enhanced oxygen transfer to plant roots, resulting in improved growth rates and nutrient uptake. This application has significant implications for sustainable food production and urban agriculture.In the context of bioreactors, Bredwell et al. (1995) reported that microbubbles could enhance mass transfer in microbial fermentation processes, leading to increased productivity and efficiency in the production of various food ingredients and additives.Environmental and Economic Considerations:The adoption of microbubble technology in food processing offers potential environmental benefits. Temesgen et al. (2017) highlighted the energy-saving potential of microbubble-based processes, particularly in aeration and mixing applications. The reduced energy consumption associated with microbubble generation and utilization can contribute to more sustainable food production practices.From an economic perspective, the low intrinsic cost of microbubble generation, coupled with their diverse applications, makes them an attractive option for food manufacturers. However, Leong et al. (2009) noted that the initial investment in microbubble generation equipment and the need for process optimization might present challenges for widespread adoption in the short term.Future Directions and Challenges:While microbubbles show great promise in food technology, several challenges need to be addressed for their widespread adoption. Stability and control of microbubble size distribution remain critical issues, as highlighted by Stride and Edirisinghe (2008). Further research is needed to develop robust methods for producing stable microbubbles with tailored properties for specific food applications.Additionally, regulatory considerations and consumer acceptance of microbubble-enhanced foods require attention. As with any novel food technology, ensuring food safety and addressing potential consumer concerns will be crucial for the successful integration of microbubbles into food products and processes.In conclusion, microbubbles offer a wide range of potential applications in food technology, from enhancing cleaning and disinfection processes to improving food properties and supporting sustainable production methods. As research in this field continues to advance, it is likely that microbubbles will play an increasingly important role in addressing challenges related to food safety, quality, and sustainability in the coming years.
